Methanol conversion to high value-added dimethyl ether (DME) and formaldehyde (FA) are important chemical reactions, commercially catalyzed by metal oxide or noble metal catalysts that are environmentally unfriendly and high cost. Borocarbonitride (BCN), as a new metal-free material, holds acid sites and multiple oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) sites, which shows powerful potential in methanol conversion reactions. Herein, a two-dimensional BCN nanosheet material was prepared through polymerization and subsequent pyrolysis, demonstrating remarkable reaction kinetics and high catalytic efficiency in methanol conversion reaction. Kinetic measurements and structural characterizations unraveled that the carboxyl (COOH) was active site of methanol intermolecular dehydration to DME, and the carbonyl (CO) and boron hydroxyl (BOH) groups were active sites of ODH of methanol to FA. Additionally, the studies indicated that the CH bond dissociation of methanol was rate-determining step of ODH reaction, while the both CH and OH bond activations had profound effect for dehydration reaction. Graphical abstract The reaction kinetics and mechanisms are unraveled in BCN catalyzed methanol conversion reaction. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Borocarbonitride Methanol conversion Kinetics Reaction mechanism Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The transformation of low quality platform molecules into high value-added chemicals is of great significance in chemical production [1]. Especially, the efficient conversion of methanol is one of the most important research topics in the energy and chemical industries. Methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde (FA) or dehydration to dimethyl ether (DME) has been extensively investigated in recent decades [2,3]. In the process of methanol dehydrogenation to FA, traditional catalysts such as molybdenum, silver, and iron-molybdenum (Fe-Mo) oxides are commonly applied [4]. The industrial silver-based catalysts require a high temperature of 560–600 °C with methanol conversion at ∼70 %, and FA selectivity at ∼90 % [5]. Compared to the silver catalytic process, the both methanol conversion and FA selectivity are above 90 % over Fe-Mo catalysts at relatively lower temperatures, while excess air is indispensable to ensure high methanol conversion [6]. In methanol dehydration to DME, the γ-Al2O3 is commercially used for this reaction, but the catalyst gradually loses its activity due to the adsorption of water over Al2O3 [7]. In brief, although these metal-based catalysts show high catalytic activity, they all have significant drawbacks, such as high preparation cost, poor catalyst stability and catalyst toxicity. Therefore, it is urgent to explore inexpensive and green catalysts to replace traditional metal catalysts. Recently, borocarbonitride (BCN) materials have attracted extensive research interests in the field of material science and chemistry [8–11]. BCN, different from B, N-codoped nanocarbon material, is comprised by hybridization of BN domains and graphene domains on nanoscale, and which exhibits high specific surface area, rich pore structure and adjustable surface acidity and basicity [12–14]. BCN are applied in many catalytic reactions, especially for oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of alcohols and alkanes, showing outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity for the target products [15,16]. For instance, Xie et al. revealed that BCN material with single C atom doping had a good performance in ODH of propane to propylene [17], while C cluster doped BCN displayed high activity in ODH of ethylbenzene [18]. Lu et al. reported BCN catalyst with nonmetallic BN embedded graphitic carbon exhibited a high styrene selectivity of 94 % at a level of 41 % conversion [19]. It is generally believed that surface carbonyl (CO) and boron hydroxyl (BOH) groups of BCN are active sites of alkane ODH [20,21]. In the CO site catalysis, the alkane molecule first adsorbs on CO sites, and then capture two hydrogen from the substrate in sequence, meanwhile, the CO are reduced into COH species. The resultant alkene desorbs from the surface of catalyst, and the COH are reoxidized into CO under the assistance of O2 molecule to finish a reaction cycle [22]. Differing from CO catalysis, the catalytic mechanism of BOH includes the following steps: (1) BOH group (Lewis acid) is firstly oxidized by O2 to form a bridging oxygen functional group (BOOB); (2) CH bonds of alkane molecule breaks on the BOOB functional group (Lewis base) to produce the corresponding olefin molecule; (3) H proton extracted from the alkane molecule combines with the electron-rich BOOB functional group to form the reduced state BOH, thus completing a catalytic cycle [23]. Currently, the numerous studies primarily focus on the preparation of BCN materials and their reaction mechanism in the ODH of alkane, however, there is few reports about the applications of BCN in methanol reaction. Unlike alkane dehydrogenation, methanol conversion, which involve in multiple elementary reaction, are complicated chemical reactions [24]. Previous reports confirmed that methanol conversion could happen over BCN materials [25], but lacks the understanding of reaction dynamic behavior and mechanism. And it is crucial to unravel these fundamental scientific issues for designing and preparing highly efficient BCN catalysts in methanol conversion reaction. Here, a two-dimensional BCN nanosheet catalyst was synthesized by the method of polymerization and pyrolysis. The present BCN nanosheets possessed high surface area and abundant surface functional groups, which was applied in methanol conversion reactions. The reaction kinetics and mechanisms of BCN catalyzed methanol conversion were systematically studied combining in situ infrared, isotope labelling, and chemical poison experiments. The results indicated that the carboxyl (COOH) was responsible for formation of DME, and the carbonyl (CO) and boron hydroxyl (BOH) groups could achieve methanol ODH to FA. Additionally, FA formation rate was constrained by activation of CH bond of methyl, while DME formation rate was affected by CH and OH bonds of methanol. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals 3-aminophenylboronic acid (98 %+), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (99 %+), and 1,4-phenylenediamine (98 %+) were purchased from Adamas-beta (Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd). All reagents were directly used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of BCN catalyst 0.002 mol of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and 0.002 mol of 3-aminophenylboronic acid were dissolved in 40 mL of methanol at room temperature (RT). After stirring for 10 h at room temperature (RT), 0.008 mol 1,4-phenylenediamine was added to the above reaction system, the red-brown solid was produced by continuing the reaction at RT for 24 h. After washing with methanol and deionized water, the solid sample was obtained by vacuum drying for 12 h. The final sample was pyrolyzed at 1000 °C for 4 h under protection of N2, and corresponding product was named as BCN. 2.3 Characterizations TEM and elemental mapping images were collected using a Talos F200S transmission electron microscope from FEI Company in the USA, with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV and a current of 65.5 μA. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the samples was performed on a STA449F3 thermal analyzer produced by Netzsch Company in Germany, under an air atmosphere, with a heating rate of 20 °C/min from 40 °C to 900 °C. The structure information of the catalyst was detected by Nicolet iS50 infrared spectrometer from Thermo Fisher Co., LTD., whose wavelength range was set as 400–4000 cm−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out by RIGAKU Ultima IV diffractometer, and diffraction patterns were collected via using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation at a scanning rate of 15° min−1 from 5° to 80° Raman spectra were performed using a Renishaw inVia with 532 nm laser excitation. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm was measured using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Plus analyzers at 77 K. Specific surface area of catalyst was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and pore size distribution was calculated by DFT method. XPS measurements were carried out using ESCALAB 250 with a source gun of Al Kα with a spot size of 500 μm. CH3OH-TPSR (Temperature Programmed Surface Reaction) experiments were performed on a self-built micro-reaction device and an online mass spectrometer. 2.4 Performance evaluation of catalyst The catalytic activity of BCN was evaluated in methanol conversion reaction. 100 mg BCN catalyst was added into reaction tube and placed in a constant temperature heating zone. He (99.999 %) was used as carrier gas and balance gas. Oxygen (O2, 99.999 %) and methanol (CH3OH, 99 %) were introduced into reaction room with total gas flow rate of 6000 mL h−1 g−1 after homogeneous mixing, and their partial pressure were adjusted to give the desired O2 and methanol concentrations. On-line analysis of reactant and product concentrations was performed using a gas chromatograph (SP-2100A, Beijing Ruili) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID), where He, O2, CO, CO2 formaldehyde (FA) species were identified and quantified by TCD and methanol, dimethyl ether (DME), dimethoxymethane (DMM) were detected and quantified via FID. Conversion was calculated by the ratio of total number of carbon atoms in the product and sum of the number of carbon atoms in the product and the number of carbon atoms in the remaining reactant. Conversion ( % ) = ∑ i N p , i C p , i ∑ i N p , i C p , i + ∑ i N r , i C r , i × 100 % Selectivity was defined as the ratio of total number of carbon atoms in the target product and the total number of carbon atoms in all products. S p , i ( % ) = N p , i C p , i ∑ i N p , i C p , i × 100 % Carbon balance was calculated by the ratio of total number of carbon atoms in the product and the remaining reactant and total number of carbon atoms in the initial reactant. Carbon balance ( % ) = ∑ i N p , i C p , i + ∑ i N r , i C r , i N C 0 × 100 % where p represents product; r represents reactant; i is symbol of summation; N represents number of carbon atom in the reactant or product; C 0 is initial molar concentration of reactant. Kinetic studies were performed in the kinetically controlled regime. The apparent activation energy (Ea) was determined from the Arrhenius equation: k = A e x p ( − E a / R T ) where, “k” is the reaction constant, “A” represents the pre-exponential factor, “R” is the gas constant (8.3145 J mol−1 K−1), “T” represents the reaction temperature, and Ea was calculated from the slope of the lnk versus 1000/T plot. Reaction order of reactant and product were calculated based on the general rate equation: r = k c n where “r” is conversion rate of reactant or formation rate of product, “k” represents rate constant, “c” is reactant or product concentration, and “n” is reaction order. The reaction orders for each individual reaction and the overall process were determined by measuring the apparent product formation rate (r) as a function of reactant concentration (partial pressure). 2.5 Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) experiment TPSR experiment was carried out on the fixed-bed reactor, with outlet gases analyzed by mass spectrum. 100 mg sample was loaded into reaction tube and was saturated with methanol (1 kPa) for 60 min at 80 °C. Stopping the methanol inlet, the pure He (10 mL/min) was applied to purge instable methanol for 30 min. After the temperature cooling down to 30 °C, TPSR data was recorded from 30 to 300 °C with heating rate of 10 °C /min at a flowing He of 10 mL/min. 2.6 NH3-TPD experiment NH3 temperature programed desorption (NH3-TPD) was carried out on a BELCAT Ⅱ. 200 mg of BCN was pretreated in He for 30 min at 300 °C to remove water and other adsorbate. After cooling down to 50 °C, the sample was saturated with NH3 (7.5 % NH3/He, 30 mL/min) for 30 min. Following, the pure He (30 mL/min) was applied to purge instable NH3 for 30 min. NH3-TPD data was recorded from 50 to 800 °C with a flowing He of 30 mL/min. 2.7 Selective poisoning of oxygenated groups on BCN The carbonyl was poisoned by phenylhydrazine (PH). Typically, 200 mg BCN sample, 500 mg PH, and 20 μL HCl were added into 100 mL of CHCl3 and stirred for 72 h with N2 protection. The obtained product was rinsed using the Soxhlet extractor with CHCl3 for 24 h to remove the adsorbed PH substrate. The sample was washed by 500 mL CHCl3 and dried at 60 °C for 12 h in vacuum. The final sample was denoted as BCN-PH. The hydroxyl group was selectively deactivated by a similar procedure. 200 mg BCN sample, 1 g benzoic anhydride (BA) were added into 100 mL of CHCl3 and stirred for 24 h with N2 protection. The obtained sample was rinsed by CHCl3 and then dried at 60 °C for 12 h in vacuum. The final product was named as BCN-BA. To poison carboxylic acid groups, 500 mg 2-bromoacetophenone (BrPE) and 200 mg BCN were dispersed in 100 mL of CHCl3 and reacted for 5 h at room temperature with protection of N2. the precipitate was washed using 500 mL of CHCl3 and dried at 60 °C for 12 h in vacuum to obtain BCN- BrPE sample. 2.8 In situ DRIFTS experiment of BCN The in-situ DRIFT was conducted under the similar reaction condition. 5 mg BCN sample mixed with 100 mg KBr and was heated to 240 °C in the IR chamber with He flow. The O2 (O2 flow rate = 4 mL/min, total flow rate = 10 mL/min) was inlet into reaction system to observe the variation of surface oxygen functional groups. After purging with He, the mixture of methanol/He was introduced to the BCN catalyst to gain insight into reaction process of active sites. 3 Results and discuss 3.1 Preparation and structure characterization of catalyst BCN material were prepared via two-step polymerization reactions and subsequent pyrolysis strategy. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the precursor 1 was synthesized via condensation reaction of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and 3-aminophenylboronic acid, and the precursor 1 further reacted with excess 1,4-phenylenediamine to form precursor 2. The resultant precursor 2, containing B, C, N and O elements, could produce BCN material via pyrolysis under 1000 °C. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to get insight into morphology and structure information of BCN. As shown in Fig. 1b and c, BCN sample displayed two-dimensional nanosheet morphology with slight stacking. In addition, high resolution TEM image (Fig. 1d) indicated the existence of turbostratic graphitic structure via observation of distorted lattice fringe in BCN structure. The elemental mapping images and EDX results (Fig. 1e) corroborated that B (1.28 at.%), C (86.43 at.%), N (2.33 at.%), and O (9.96 at.%) elements were uniformly distributed over BCN, suggesting formation of ternary BCN structure. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed to analyze the crystalline phase structure of the final material. From XRD pattern of BCN in Fig. 2 a, there were two broad peaks at 24.6° and 43°, which belonged to the (002) and (100) crystal planes of typical graphite, respectively [26], indicating small BN patch doped carbon structure. Raman spectrum (Fig. 2b) of BCN material showed two peaks at 1350 cm−1 and 1580 cm−1, corresponding to the graphitic lattice defects (D) and ideal graphitic lattice (G) structure, respectively. A higher intensity of D peak suggested that B and N were successfully introduced to carbon matrix. The BET surface area and pore size distribution of BCN was measured through N2 physical adsorption-desorption. As depicted in Fig. 2c, BCN exhibited type-I isotherm that the adsorption amount of N2 rised sharply in the low pressure region (P/P0 < 0.1) and quickly reached balance, indicating that micropores mainly existed in BCN. The pore size distribution of BCN material was determined by DFT model and mainly concentrated in the range of 0.4–2 nm (Fig. S1). However, the BET specific surface area of BCN could reach 597 m2 g−1, which was conducive to increasing the utilization of active sites and the mass transfer. The attenuated total reflection-infrared (IR) was used to investigate surface functional group of BCN (Fig. 2d). The broad peak at 3220 cm−1 represented stretching vibration of OH [27], and peaks at 2970 and 1440 cm−1 were ascribed to stretching and bending vibration of CH. The BN structure could be confirmed by stretching vibration of BN (1375 cm−1) and bending vibration of BNB (815 cm−1) [28]. The IR signal of CO stretching vibration could be observed at 1600 cm−1. The peaks at 1262 and 1101 cm−1 are corresponding to stretching vibration of CN and BC, which further confirmed ternary BCN structure [29,30]. Other peaks were attributed to signals of CO and BO [31,32]. All these results evidenced that B and N elements were successfully doped into the carbon structure in the form of BN, and active functional groups, such as BO and CO were present [25]. To further analyze the surface elemental composition and chemical states of the as-prepared material, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on BCN sample. The elemental composition is 2.26 % (B), 87.29 % (C), 2.68 % (N), and 7.77 % (O). B 1s (Fig. S2a) XPS spectrum could be fitted into three peaks, corresponding to BC at 189.6 eV, BN at 191.27 eV, and BO at 192.53 eV [33,34], respectively. XPS fine spectrum of C 1s (Fig. S2b) can be deconvoluted into five peaks associated with BC at 283.7 eV, CC at 284.6 eV, CC at 285.4 eV, CN at 286.1 eV, and CO at 287.9 eV [35,36], and the ratio of CC bond was dominant in BCN. The deconvolution of N 1s (Fig. S2c) XPS spectrum disclosed the existence of BN (397.6 eV), pyridinic-N (398.4 eV), pyrrolic-N (399.6 eV), graphitic-N (401.1 eV), and N oxide (402.8 eV) species [37,38]. For O 1s (Fig. 2e) XPS spectrum, four kinds of oxygen species were observed in BCN, corresponding to C = O (531.1 eV), COOH (532.3 eV), BOH (532.8 eV), and COH (533.6 eV), respectively [25,39]. These oxygen-containing functional groups are most likely to be active origins in BCN catalytic ODH reactions. The thermal stability and oxidation resistance of BCN was determined via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in air. As shown in Fig. 2f, there was a slight mass loss (5 %) before 450 °C owing to the evaporation of physically adsorbed water on the surface of BCN. When the temperature exceeded 480 °C, the mass of BCN rapidly decreased, which was mainly due to the combustion of carbon domains. The mass of sample tended to stabilize above 800 °C, and the residual weight (∼18 %) was indexed to oxidized BN species because of its high anti-oxidization [11]. TGA analysis corroborated structural stability of BCN in methanol conversion reaction. 3.2 Catalytic performance and kinetics The catalytic performance of BCN in methanol conversion reaction was evaluated in the relatively mild reaction condition. Firstly, we studied the effect of reaction temperature (220–260 °C) on catalytic activity of BCN and product selectivity. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the methanol conversion could reach 6.7 % at 220 °C, and product selectivities were 62 % for DME, 14 % for FA, 4 % for dimethoxymethane (DMM) and 20 % for CO2, respectively. There was significant activity improvement from 6.7 % to 19.2 % on methanol conversion with increasing of reaction temperature (from 220 to 260 °C). The product selectivity had also obvious difference, of which DME and DMM selectivity gradually decreased with increasing of reaction temperature, while FA selectivity gradually increased. These results indicated that low reaction temperature was conducive for dehydration reaction and high reaction temperature was more favorable for ODH reaction. It is worth noting that the selectivity of CO2 had a slight change before 240 °C, but significantly improved when reaction temperature exceeded 240 °C. Therefore, the 240 °C was chosen as reaction temperature to investigate reaction kinetics. As shown in Fig. 3b, there was some activity loss in the reaction initial period, and methanol conversion tended to be stable (∼15 %) after 200 min, with DME selectivity at 59 %, FA selectivity at 18 %, DMM selectivity at 3 %, and CO2 selectivity at 20 %. Meanwhile, the BCN displayed 1200 min of continuous operation without observable activity attenuation, and no significant morphology and structure changes were observed in the spent catalyst by XRD and TEM analyses (Figs. S3 and S4), which demonstrated exceptional catalytic stability of BCN. Critically, BCN showed also superior catalytic performance compared to traditional carbon materials (Fig. S5), such as oxidized carbon nanotube (oCNT), nanocarbon, B4C, and activated carbon (AC). The apparent activation energy (Ea) was determined by Arrhenius equation (k = Ae-Ea/RT ). As depicted in Fig. 3c, the Ea of methanol conversion on BCN was 49.7 kJ/mol in the reaction temperature of 220–260 °C, which was lower than these of metal-based and nanocarbon catalyst [24,40], implying that BCN material had a lower reaction energy barrier in methanol ODH. To study the reaction pathway and catalytic mechanism of BCN in methanol conversion reaction, kinetic experiments were carried out under choosing reaction conditions. Here we explored effects of methanol and O2 partial pressure on ODH and dehydration rates. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the reaction rate of methanol ODH to FA rose with increasing of O2 partial pressure, while dehydration rate of methanol to DME showed opposite trend. Distinct from the effect of O2 partial pressure, the both methanol ODH and dehydration rate increased with methanol partial pressure (Fig. 4c). The relevant equations of methanol conversion into different products and the overall reaction equation were summarized as follows: (1) CH3OH + O2 → CH3OCH2OCH3 + H2O (2) CH3OH → CH3OCH3 + H2O (3) CH3OH + O2 → HCHO + H2O (4) CH3OH + O2 → CO2 + H2O (5) CH3OH + O2 → CH3OCH3 + HCHO + CO2 + CH3OCH2OCH3 + H2O Eqs. (1)–(4) represented the individual reaction of methanol conversion to DMM, DME, FA, and CO2, respectively, and Eq. (5) was the overall reaction for methanol conversion. Based on the definition of reaction order (r = kc ո, where ո is the reaction order), the reaction order of O2 and methanol for the individual reactions and overall reaction were calculated. The Eq. (1) was not considered because of extremely low DMM concentration. As shown in Fig. 4b and d, the reaction orders of O2 were −0.19, 0.27, 0.21 and 0.35, and the reaction orders of methanol were 0.41, 0.48, −0.1 and 0.35 for Eqs. (2)–(5), respectively. In Eq. (2), the reaction order of methanol was 0.41 and the reaction order of O2 was −0.19, suggesting that the higher methanol concentration could facilitate the formation of DME but increasing the concentration of O2 was not conducive to the formation of DME. This was because the methanol ODH to FA and the dehydration to DME were competitive reactions. In Eq. (3), the reaction orders of methanol and O2 were 0.48 and 0.27, respectively, implying that the both higher methanol and O2 partial pressure were beneficial for FA formation and the former was prominent. In Eq. (4), O2 partial pressure showed more profound effect on the formation rate of CO2 than that of methanol, indicating that an appropriate O2 partial pressure in the reaction system was necessary to improve FA and DME selectivities. In the overall reaction, the reaction orders of methanol and O2 were 0.35 and 0.025, suggesting that the methanol partial pressure had a profound influence on methanol conversion rate. Kinetic isotope effect (KIE) is an efficient tool to determine the rate-determining steps in the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) and dehydration of methanol. The deuterated methanol, including CH3OD and CD3OH, were used to study the KIE in methanol conversion reactions. Due to the mass difference between H and D in the reactant molecules, the product formation rate would change significantly when switching CH3OH to CH3OD or CD3OH. As shown in Fig. 5 a, there was a negligible change for FA formation rate when CH3OD was used instead of CH3OH with steady-state rate ratio of RCH3OH/RCH3OD = 1.13, suggesting a negligible KIE. However, FA formation rate reduced sharply when switching reactants from CH3OH to CD3OH, exhibiting a significant KIE with steady-state rate ratio of RCH 3 OH/RCH3OD = 4.21. The studies indicated that the CH bond rather than OH cleavage was the rate-determining step in methanol ODH to FA reaction. In the methanol dehydration to DME, when CH3OD was used instead of CH3OH, the DME formation rate decreased slightly with RCH3OH/RCH3OD = 1.35 (Fig. 5b), indicating a minor KIE. Interestingly, the KIE was remarkable when CD3OH was used with steady-state rate ratio of RCH3OH/RCH3OD = 1.81. This result was somewhat unexpected because dehydration of methanol to DME usually did not involve cleavage of CH bonds. Based on these discoveries, it can be inferred that the methanol conversion to DME catalyzed by BCN was affected by OH and CH bond breakage, but the reaction pathway remained to be further explored. Fig. 5c showed the effect of methanol isotopes on the formation rate of CO2. There was a minimal variation on CO2 formation rate when the feeding gas was changed to CH3OD (RCH3OH/RCH3OD = 1.16), yet CO2 formation rate showed the observable decrease when switching reactant from CH3OH to CD3OH (RCH3OH/RCD3OH = 1.38), which implied that the CH breakage had a more profound impact on methanol complete oxidation than that of OH bond cleavage. These results provided insights into the details of the catalytic conversion of methanol on BCN materials. 3.3 Identification of reactive active site The active sites and reaction mechanisms in BCN catalyzed methanol conversion reaction were revealed via chemical poison and in-situ FTIR experiments, and temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR). The phenylhydrazine (PH), benzoic anhydride (BA) and 2-bromo-1-phenylethane (BrPE) were applied as poison reagents to selectively remove CO, BOH, and COOH oxygen functional groups [41,42]. As shown in Fig. 6 a, DME formation rate notably reduced and FA formation rate had a slight change after COOH site poisoning, suggesting that COOH was active site of methanol dehydration to DME. NH3 temperature programed desorption (NH3-TPD) was utilized to examine the acidity of BCN. As shown in Fig. S6, the BCN exhibited an adsorption of NH3 prior to 130 °C, suggesting the existence of weak acid sites, while adsorption at 415 °C corresponded to strong acid sites. This further demonstrated that the high dehydration activity of BCN was driven by its acid sites. Similarly, when BOH or CO groups were poisoned, FA formation rate decreased to half of that before poison, which indicated that both CO and BOH were responsible for methanol ODH to FA. In-situ IR experiments was performed to further get insight into reaction mechanism. As depicted in Fig. 6b, the peak intensity of CO group at 1600 cm−1 gradually increased after introduction of O2, indicating the CO group was formed on BCN. Whereas, IR signal of CO weakened when switching reactants from O2 to methanol (Fig. 6c), which was attributed to the consumption of CO sites. These results further confirmed that CO was active sites of methanol ODH to FA. It's worth noting that the catalytic process of BOH was not detected due to the low concentration of BOH. In order to observe the change of intermediate products during the reaction, the fixed bed reactor coupled with the mass spectrometer experiments was applied. The baseline of the mass spectrometer was stabilized via He sweeping. Subsequently, 0.5 kPa methanol was introduced into the fixed bed reactor, and the redox reaction and acid-catalyzed reaction started on the BCN to produce various products. As shown in Figs. 6d and S7, the signals of FA and H2 were immediately detected in the mass spectrometer once methanol was introduced into reaction system. These results showed that methanol direct dehydrogenation to FA could happen on CO and BOH sites. Notably, the CO and BOH sites were continuously consumed under the absence of O2, leading to signal attenuation of FA and H2. Moreover, the formations of DME and H2O further confirmed dehydration reaction of methanol on BCN (Fig. 6e and f), and process of which did not require the participation of O2. He was used to sweep the residues after stopping inlet of methanol, and O2 was introduced into reaction system after that. It could be seen that there was an obvious H2O signal enhancement, which was due to the regeneration of CO and BOOB sites with assistance of O2 [43,44]. In order to further investigate the adsorption and desorption of methanol and products on the BCN catalyst surface, the temperature programed desorption (TPD) of methanol was performed. The BCN sample was saturated with methanol under 80 °C. As shown in Fig. S8, methanol molecules firstly desorbed from BCN as the temperature increased. Subsequently, FA desorbed from BCN owing to the direct dehydrogenation of methanol, which was good agreement with the TPSR results. DME was finally desorbed from BCN, suggesting that DME had a stronger chemisorption on the surface of BCN than those of methanol and FA, and required a higher desorption temperature. Based on the above experimental results and previous studies, we proposed the reaction mechanism of BCN catalyzed methanol ODH reaction. As depicted in Scheme 1 , at the CO site, methanol molecules were firstly adsorbed, and then the two adjacent CO molecules successively abstracted H atoms from methyl (rate-determining step) and hydroxyl groups of methanol to generate FA product, meanwhile, CO sites were reduced into COH. The COH was reoxidized to CO with the assistance of O2 to finish a catalytic cycle. On the other hand, at the BOH site, two adjacent BOH sites firstly were oxidized to form BOOB site with formation of H2O, and then BOOB sequentially captured two H atoms in the methanol molecule to produce FA, and the BOOB site was reduced to BOH to complete a reaction cycle. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we applied small organic molecules containing B, C and N as precursors to synthesize two-dimensional BCN nanosheet material with graphene-like structures through prepolymerization and high temperature pyrolysis. The prepared BCN had a high specific surface area and rich active oxygen functional groups (including CO, COOH and BOH), which could act as a model catalyst to explore the kinetics and mechanism in methanol conversion reaction. Kinetic measurements showed that low reaction temperature was favorable for the formation of DME, and high temperature for the formation of FA in BCN catalyzed methanol conversion reaction. KIE results corroborated that the cleavage of CH bond was the rate-determining step in the methanol ODH to FA, and the breakages of both CH and OH of methanol could affect the formation rate of DME. The poison and in-situ FTIR experiments confirmed that COOH was active site of methanol intermolecular dehydration to DME, and the CO and BOH groups were active sites of ODH of methanol to FA. In addition, combining TPSR and TPD experiments monitored the formation process of various products, and obtained the information of different product desorption. This work provided a more comprehensive understanding of the intrinsic reaction process of methanol ODH and dehydration catalyzed by BCN, and was of great help to establish the structure-function relationship and design new BCN catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Methanol conversion to high value-added dimethyl ether (DME) and formaldehyde (FA) are important chemical reactions, commercially catalyzed by metal oxide or noble metal catalysts that are environmentally unfriendly and high cost. Borocarbonitride (BCN), as a new metal-free material, holds acid sites and multiple oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) sites, which shows powerful potential in methanol conversion reactions. Herein, a two-dimensional BCN nanosheet material was prepared through polymerization and subsequent pyrolysis, demonstrating remarkable reaction kinetics and high catalytic efficiency in methanol conversion reaction. Kinetic measurements and structural characterizations unraveled that the carboxyl (COOH) was active site of methanol intermolecular dehydration to DME, and the carbonyl (CO) and boron hydroxyl (BOH) groups were active sites of ODH of methanol to FA. Additionally, the studies indicated that the CH bond dissociation of methanol was rate-determining step of ODH reaction, while the both CH and OH bond activations had profound effect for dehydration reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetic and mechanistic understanding of methanol conversion on borocarbonitride catalyst
